FacilityName: U.S. Energy Partners, LLC DBA White Energy

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

US Energy Partners, LLC DBA White Energy (White Energy)



This RMP resubmission is to fulfill the 5-year update requirement of CAA Section 112(r).



White Energy was the first ethanol plant in the U.S. to become part of OSHA's Safety and Health Achievement Recognition Program (SHARPS).



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

White Energy has an ongoing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as, personnel training on the proper operation and maintenance of plant equipment and preventative maintenance programs.



White Energy has emergency response policies in place that are addressed in the following documents: Health and Safety Plan, Industrial Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan, Spill Prevention, Controls, and Countermeasures Plan, and Facility Response Plan (with Emergency Response Action Plan).  Most of the documents listed have a minimum of annual training requirements to keep employees educated on emergency response procedures in place at the plant.  Employees (in specific job roles) are required to read and be familiar with the contents of the above-listed plans.



White Energy's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release as necessary.



DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

White Energy is located in Russell, Russell County, Kansas.  The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from waste starch water and corn.  The regulated substance under the RMP program is Denaturant (also known as natural gasoline which is a flammable mixture).  



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS:

The worst-case scenario at the facility is based on the release of the entire contents of

the denaturant aboveground storage tank (39,000 gallons) followed by ignitition, causing a vapor cloud explosion.  The denaturant tank is located within a diked containment structure that contains an impermeable liner with gravel overlay.  This secondary containment structure was not used as a passive mitigation measure when determining the worst case scenario for denaturant.  A worst case MSDS was used to determine intial RMP applicablity, White Energy continues to use this worst case MSDS for this RMP resubmission.  Of the entire tank contents, totalling 218,400 pounds, only 74,256 pounds are considered reportable constituents under the RMP program.  RMP Comp was used to determine the worst case distance to endpoint, model results are maintained with this RMP in facility records.  Public receptor information was obtained using LandView 6, records are maintained with this RMP in facility records.  No environmental receptors are affected by a worst case release of denaturant.  



The alternate scenario used for the flammable mixture is the release of 50,400 pounds of denaturant due to a tanker truck loadout spill, causing a vapor cloud fire.  The endpoint used was an overpressurization of 1 PSI, a worst case option.  Denaturant deliveries at the facility typically occur during normal business hours with a facility staff member overseeing loadout operations.  Therefore, a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides.  The loadout area also has a catchment basin with underground piping that leads to the lined tank farm berm for secondary containment.  For this scenario, active and passive mitigation was not considered, as the mitigation strategies currently in place at the facility would not contain a vapor cloud fire. RMP Comp was used to determine the alternate distance to endpoint, model results are maintained with this RMP in facility records.  Public receptor information was obtained using LandView 6, records are maintained with

this RMP in facility records.  No environmental receptors are affected by an alternate case release of denaturant.  



The facility qualifies as a Program 2.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

Please review the first section of this Executive Summary for the general accidental release prevention program information.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

There has not been a release of denaturant at the White Energy facility.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

White Energy has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including a Health and Safety Plan and Facility Response Plan - that includes an Emergency Response Action Plan detailing evacuation and response procedures for spills/releases, fires/explosions, etc.  The Plans listed in this Executive Summary have been developed and implemented in accordance with applicable regulatory standards, as necessary.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

White Energy will continue to provide training programs to ensure the safety of employees and contractors.
